newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: Korea semiconductor group urges speedy tariff cut.
newsitem.headline: Korea semiconductor group urges speedy tariff cut.

text.p: The Korean Semiconductor Industry Association has asked the government to speed up the scheduled elimination of tariffs on imported chips, the group said on Tuesday.
South Korea has already committed itself to the World Trade Organisation to cut the tariffs from eight percent to four percent by 1998 and to zero by 1999.
"The association, as a representative of Korean semiconductor producers, is asking the government to accelerate the elimination of tariffs on semiconductors," an association statement said.

An association official said South Korea, which plans to participate in the World Semiconductor Council led by the United States and Japan, must drop tariffs on semiconductors sooner rather than later.

"The earlier elimination of tariffs would help expand the demand of semiconductors and would benefit the Korean economy," said association vice chairman Kim Chi-luck. "Internationally, it will contribute to expanding global free trade."
He also said it would contribute to honing international competitiveness of South Korean electronics manufacturers which have relied on imports for 75 percent of their semiconductor demand.

South Korea ranks number three in the world dynamic random access memory (DRAM) chip production but lags in the non-memory chip fields such as micro-processors and application specific integrated circuits.
Semiconductors represent about 20 percent of South Korea's total exports but falling prices have hit the country's overseas shipments hard.

The state-funded Korea Institute for Industrial Economics and Trade forecast on Tuesday that semiconductor exports would fall to $16.5 billion this year from $22.1 billion last year. This is even lower than the trade ministry's revised forecast of $18 billion.
Yonhap news agency said South Korea's trade shortfall for the whole of 1996 might exceed $20 billion if semiconductor exports fell as the institute forecast.
